Multiple-value fields made explicitAs it turns out, Solr can only order by single-value fields - so, wenneed to make an explicit distinction between single-value andnmultiple-value fields in the configuration. Use FilterQueries for scope & conditionsScope and Condition queries now use FilterQueries instead of being ANDedninto the main query. All query components respond to #to_paramsQuery and Restriction objects respond to #to_params, which generates anhash representing the solr-ruby parameters associated with the querynarguments that they represent. Created Solr::Util::deep_merge() methodnto agnostically merge the params together. Several advantages here -nfirst, newer query components (e.g., facets) will be able to simplynimplement this method with little change to the contianing object. Also,nSunspot::Search object no longer has to know much of anything about thenway Solr is queried. Finally, it will be easier to make the switch tonRSolr (which transparently passes params to Solr).n

Dynamic fields are typedThe first implementation inferred the storage type from the class of the objectnencountered for search/indexing, but I decided to change it for a few reasons:nn- Basing behavior on input type in Ruby is generally considered an anti-pattern;n  for instance, I may want to pass in a string representation of an integer andn  have it treated as an integer, if I've so specified.n- Type inference is not possible when specifying dynamic fields for faceting orn  indexing, since the query doesn't encounter a concrete value until results aren  returned (which is, of course far too late). So, it would be necessary ton  explicitly specify which type of field is desired for faceting/ordering, whichn  presents an inconsistent API.n- The implementation is cleaner, probably largely due to the avoidance ofn  logical inconsistencies outlined above.n

Eliminated value sorting for range scopes.Rationale:nnI think this is an issue that is better handled by the applicationndeveloper, not Sunspot.  If a range _r_ is provided for which r.first >nr.last, it is an issue, but it can (it should!) be solved by thenapplication developer.  Some examples:nn* The application developer screwed up range construction.  In thisn  case, there is an error lurking in the application code, and Sunspotn  should not mask this error.n* The application developer is using user input in range construction,n  the user entered in values for first and last such that first > last,n  and the application does not check that first < last is true.  This,n  again, is an error lurking in the application code, and Sunspot shouldn  not mask this error.n* The application developer wants to use ranges merely for theirn  syntax, not their semantics.  (Sunspot's between scope already doesn  this in the sense that it uses ranges merely as a convenient valuen  container.)  Given that, the below is something that makes sense ton  do:nnwith(:key).between('9'..'11')nn  However, because '9' > '11' by lexicographical ordering, Sunspot willn  turn this into something likennfq=key_i:[11 TO 9]nn  when, without sorting, it would generate the expectednnfq=key_i:[9 TO 11]nn  The only way to currently solve this is to coerce those strings to ann  appropriate numeric type, which seems unnecessary, since these queriesn  work fine with string inputs.nn[#109 state:resolved]n

Send parameters in the body, not the query string.The version of Jetty bundled with Sunspot (as of this commit) aggregatesnquery parameters and POST data when it presents parameters to a webapp.nnWinstone 0.9.10, which otherwise runs Solr well, doesn't do this.nSending POST /select to Winstone yields a response with a 500 statusncode and report errors like this in the log:nnINFO: [] webapp=/solr path=/select params={} status=500 QTime=1nOct 10, 2011 12:31:00 AM org.apache.solr.common.SolrException lognSEVERE: java.lang.NullPointerExceptionn  at java.io.StringReader.<init>(StringReader.java:33)n  at org.apache.lucene.queryParser.QueryParser.parse(QueryParser.java:197)n  at org.apache.solr.search.LuceneQParser.parse(LuceneQParserPlugin.java:78)n  at org.apache.solr.search.QParser.getQuery(QParser.java:131)n  at org.apache.solr.handler.component.QueryComponent.prepare(QueryComponent.java:89)n  at org.apache.solr.handler.component.SearchHandler.handleRequestBody(SearchHandler.java:174)n  at org.apache.solr.handler.RequestHandlerBase.handleRequest(RequestHandlerBase.java:131)n  at org.apache.solr.core.SolrCore.execute(SolrCore.java:1316)n  at org.apache.solr.servlet.SolrDispatchFilter.execute(SolrDispatchFilter.java:338)n  at org.apache.solr.servlet.SolrDispatchFilter.doFilter(SolrDispatchFilter.java:241)n  at winstone.FilterConfiguration.execute(FilterConfiguration.java:195)n  at winstone.RequestDispatcher.doFilter(RequestDispatcher.java:368)n  at winstone.RequestDispatcher.forward(RequestDispatcher.java:333)n  at winstone.RequestHandlerThread.processRequest(RequestHandlerThread.java:244)n  at winstone.RequestHandlerThread.run(RequestHandlerThread.java:150)n  at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:680)nnwhich looks like Solr is receiving POST /select with no parameters.nnTo be fair, I think Winstone is actually violating Servlet API v2.4 innthis case.  Section SRV.4.1 of the API specification states Data fromnthe query string and the post body are aggregated into the requestnparameter set, which doesn't seem to be happening here. Update sunspot servers for booting solr 5* Solr 5 is no longer designed to be run through its jar file. Instead,nsolr includes the handy `bin/solr` executable.
